title: Position graph from table of velocity values

content.question: The table gives selected values of the velocity, v(t), of a particle moving along the x-axis. At time t = 0 , the particle is at the origin. Which of the following could be the graph of the position, x(t), of the particle for 0 ≤ t ≤ 4 ?

choices.label: A graph plots a curve. The horizontal axis denotes t and the vertical axis denotes x of t. The curve begins at the origin, rises to the point 2 comma 4, and falls through the point 3.2 comma 0 to the point 4 comma negative 3. All values estimated.

A graph plots a curve. The horizontal axis denotes t and the vertical axis denotes x of t. The curve originates from the point 0 comma negative 1, rises to the point 2 comma 3, and falls through the point 3 comma 0 to the point 4 comma negative 4. All values estimated.

A graph plots a curve. The horizontal axis denotes t and the vertical axis denotes x of t. The curve begins at the origin, bends below the horizontal axis, rises through the point 0.7 comma 0 to a maximum point 3 comma 5, and falls to the point 4 comma 3. All values estimated.

A graph plots a curve. The horizontal axis denotes t and the vertical axis denotes x of t. The curve originates from the point 0 comma negative 1, rises through the point 0.5 comma 0 to a maximum point 2 comma 2, falls through the point 3 comma 0 into the first quadrant. All values estimated.

A graph plots a curve. The horizontal axis denotes t and the vertical axis denotes x of t. The curve begins at the origin, falls down to the point 1 comma negative 1, rises through the point 1.7 comma 0 to a maximum point 3 comma 4, and further falls down to the point 4 comma 0. All values estimated.

content.answer: A graph plots a curve. The horizontal axis denotes t and the vertical axis denotes x of t. The curve begins at the origin, bends below the horizontal axis, rises through the point 0.7 comma 0 to a maximum point 3 comma 5, and falls to the point 4 comma 3. All values estimated.

topic.text: 8.2: Connecting Position, Velocity, and Acceleration Functions Using Integrals

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
